items.title: [The Guardian Global Development] Ancient stepwells brought back to life as India begins to run out of water
items.content_html:
Centuries-old wells restored to provide drinking water as parts of the country head towards ‚Äúday zero‚Äù when no water will be available

A loud cheer and sounds of clapping reverberated around Bansilalpet, a neighbourhood in Hyderabad, when the first trickle of clean water dribbled out of the ground. After an 18-month effort to clear out 3,000 tonnes of rubbish and restore the stone walls and adjacent area, the 17th-century Bansilalpet stepwell had become a source of clean drinking water for the first time in four decades.

‚ÄúIt was such a joyous moment to see water collecting into the stepwell after clearing 40 years of garbage,‚Äù says Hajira Adeeb, a 45-year-old resident of Bansilalpet, who grew up seeing the well become transformed from the community‚Äôs water source to a dumping ground. ‚ÄúI visit almost every day. The area is clean and lit up in the evenings. I enjoy sitting there.‚Äù

Continue reading...

items.title: [Engadget] New Webb Telescope photos show off the Exposed Cranium Nebula
items.content_html:
It's always a fun day for the space nerds when a NASA team has new images to share from the James Webb Space Telescope. Today's pair has brains on the brain, with a look at the fittingly named Exposed Cranium Nebula. More officially, this cloud of space dust and debris is known as Nebula PMR 1. The images shared today may capture a moment in the final stages of a star, as well as giving hints as to how the nebula got its brain-like shape.  

"The nebula appears to have distinct regions that capture different phases of its evolution ‚Äî an outer shell of gas that was blown off first and consists mostly of hydrogen, and an inner cloud with more structure that contains a mix of different gases," NASA's blog post reads. The dark line that runs vertically through the nebula, giving it the cranial appearance, could be the result of "an outburst or outflow from the central star, which typically occurs as twin jets burst out in opposite directions." Both Webb's Near-Infrared Camera (NIRCam) and its Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) were used to document the nebula.

This article originally appeared on Engadget at https://www.engadget.com/science/space/new-webb-telescope-photos-show-off-the-exposed-cranium-nebula-235609619.html?src=rss

items.title: [Kottke.org] Physics Is a Conversation
items.content_html:
Physicist Sean Carroll leads off this video with this line:

I like to say that Einstein is, if anything, underrated as a physicist, which is hard to imagine given how highly he is rated.

And then leads us through a history of modern physics and quantum mechanics that, Einstein and Newton aside, is much more collaborative than you often hear about.

This idea that there are many people contributing and many different parts of the pieces need to put together is actually much more characteristic of how physics is usually done than the single person inventing everything all by themselves.

Tags: Albert Einstein ¬∑ physics ¬∑ science ¬∑ Sean Carroll ¬∑ video

items.title: [Boing Boing] More than 1 in 10 meditators report serious adverse effects
items.content_html:
Meditation is one of those things that seems like it can only help. Sit quietly, focus on your breath, feel calmer. But more than 1 in 10 regular practitioners report significant adverse effects ‚Äî problems like anxiety, psychotic episodes, and depersonalization that disrupted their daily functioning for a month or more, according to a 2022 US study. — Read the rest

The post More than 1 in 10 meditators report serious adverse effects appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Boing Boing] Newly found letters show Georg Cantor stole his famous infinity proof
items.content_html:
Georg Cantor's 1874 proof that infinity comes in different sizes reshaped mathematics. It also appears to have been stolen. Newly discovered letters show that Cantor's colleague Richard Dedekind provided key proofs that Cantor published under his own name, reports Quanta Magazine. — Read the rest

The post Newly found letters show Georg Cantor stole his famous infinity proof appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Boing Boing] Scientists complete the first full wiring diagram of a fruit fly brain
items.content_html:
Scientists have completed the most detailed map ever made of an adult animal brain by charting every cell and connection in a fruit fly's brain¬†(the fly brain map is ridiculously cool-looking). Despite being smaller than a pinhead, the fly's brain contains about 130,000 neurons and 50 million connections, allowing it to walk, fly, hover, and even sing mating songs. — Read the rest

The post Scientists complete the first full wiring diagram of a fruit fly brain appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Quanta Magazine] The Man Who Stole Infinity
items.content_html:
In an 1874 paper, Georg Cantor proved that there are different sizes of infinity and changed math forever. A trove of newly unearthed letters shows that it was also an act of plagiarism.

The post The Man Who Stole Infinity first appeared on Quanta Magazine

items.content_html:

items.title: [Boing Boing] An asteroid passed 428 km from Earth and no one saw it coming
items.content_html:
Last year, an asteroid called 2025 TF zipped past Antarctica at an altitude of 428 kilometers ‚Äî no higher than where the ISS orbits. Nobody saw it coming. The Catalina Sky Survey picked it up only after it had already gone by, according to a data visualization by Pascal B√ºrkle at the Datawrapper blog. — Read the rest

The post An asteroid passed 428 km from Earth and no one saw it coming appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Boing Boing] A simple blood test diagnoses Alzheimer's with 94.5% accuracy
items.content_html:
Doctors correctly diagnose Alzheimer's disease about 75.5% of the time using standard clinical evaluations. A simple blood test bumps that number to 94.5%.

The study, published in the Journal of Neurology, tracked 200 patients ‚Äî all 50 or older ‚Äî who showed up at neurology clinics in Spain with cognitive complaints. — Read the rest

The post A simple blood test diagnoses Alzheimer's with 94.5% accuracy appeared first on Boing Boing.

items.title: [Boing Boing] Scotch tape screeches because it's making tiny sonic booms
items.content_html:
Unwind a roll of Scotch tape inside a vacuum and it gives off X-rays ‚Äî enough to capture a fuzzy image of a lab member's finger. UCLA physicists demonstrated this in 2008, vindicating a claim Soviet scientists had made (to widespread disbelief) back in 1953. — Read the rest
